In short, it's an indentation problem you are having. Check the setting in idle. Insert spaces instead of tabs if not set. Or, hit the spacebar four times at the proper indentation blocks.

@Atalaa I don't use idle, but a few things come to mind.
Are you using spaces or tabs to indent? If you are using tabs and have not changed the settings to insert spaces instead of tabs, that could be a reason why you are having problems.
In your first screenshot, a possible reason for the first error is you NEED to place an expression under the else. The second error is due to indentation. Just as mstellaluna said.

The nested if statements won't work. Well, the second if statement never gets executed.

```
if a > 0:
    print("pos")
    if a < 0:
        print("neg")
```
if a is less than zero, it will never print "neg". The reason is that a first needs to be greater than zero for it to reach the second if statement. And unless it gets changed along the way (which in this example it never does) it won't hit that second if statement.

From the top.
```
def increment(n):
   n += 1
   return n

n = 1
while n < 10:
   n = increment(n)
print(n)
```
first we create a function called increment with a **parameter** n
inside the function, that parameter, whatever it is, will increment by 1
it will then return the value of n

then we set the **variable** n to 1
the while statement will continue until the condition is met. In this case, until n is less than 10.
we then reassign the variable n to the value returned by the function increment.
the while statement will break out of the loop once n is equal to 10. What this means is that it will continue to execute as long as the variable n is less than 10. However, when the variable n is 9, it will execute one more time.
we then print the value of N, which comes back as 10

some practice for you:

```
def update(n, x):

    n = 1
    x = [0, 1, 2, 3]
    print('main: ', n, x)
    update(n, x)
    print('main: ', n, x)

main()
```

code:
``` 
x = 50

def func():
    global x
    print 'This function is now using the global x!'
    print 'Because of global x is: ', x
    x = 2
    print 'Ran func(), changed global x to', x

print 'Before calling func(), x is: ', x
func()
print 'Value of x (outside of func()) is: ', x
```

roughly:
```
from flask import Flask, render_template
from flask_socketio import SocketIO

app = Flask(__name__)
app.config['SECRET_KEY'] = 'secret!'
socketio = SocketIO(app)

@socketio.on('connect')
def connect():
    emit('my response', {'data': 'Connected'})

if __name__ == '__main__':
    socketio.run(app)
```
reference: https://blog.miguelgrinberg.com/post/easy-websockets-with-flask-and-gevent

As a previous windows user, that was one of the hardest concepts for me to grasp. It was that interaction between the cmd, files and so forth. What might help seeing what is going on, open "my computer" or whatever it is called these days and open it in the same directory where you are creating the file. Just leave it open and see how it changes as you create a file. 

You can create a file / document by opening microsoft word, for example. Write some text into it, save the file, use "my computer" / the exporer to see it save in a location in the machine, in some directory (a.k.a. folder). 
You can also use a text editor to create a file. What else can one use to create files? Whatever program saves something to the computer, it is creating a file. It can be a picture, an image, sound files, so forth. All of those things that you save are files. 

Inherently, what you are doing with either %%writefile, which is a specific command for ipython - which would be the same as the button in microsoft word that saves the document. The cmd prompt would use a different command to save a file to a certain place in your computer. So it doesn't matter what you use to save a file. Since you are not using ipython, you would use cmd. Since you are using the cmd, you are probably running python. 

Now, the cmd is only a window which lets you interact with python. When you use python to write, or create a file, you are using python commands to do that. In short, you are writing a program to create a file. When you are using microsoft word and press that save button, behind that button there are a lot of lines of code to save that file. 

So, when you create a file using python, keep my computer open in the same location you are creating a file to see it show up.

I'm trying to complete this prompt: 

The input is a string str of digits. Cut the string into chunks of size sz (ignore the last chunk if its size is less than sz).

If a chunk represents an integer such as the sum of the cubes of its digits is divisible by 2, reverse it; otherwise rotate it to the left by one position. Put together these modified chunks and return the result as a string.

If

sz is <= 0 or if str is empty return ""
sz is greater (>) than the length of str it is impossible to take a chunk of size sz hence return "".
Examples:
revrot("123456987654", 6) --> "234561876549"
revrot("123456987653", 6) --> "234561356789"
revrot("66443875", 4) --> "44668753"
revrot("66443875", 8) --> "64438756"
revrot("664438769", 8) --> "67834466"
revrot("123456779", 8) --> "23456771"
revrot("", 8) --> ""
revrot("123456779", 0) --> ""

Here is my code: 

```
def revrot(string, size):

    #If input is valid, Construct a list of desired chunks
    
    if size > 0 and size > 0 and size < len(string): 
        chunks = [string[i:i+size] for i in range(0, len(string), size)]
        print 'Input: String - %s | Chunk Size - %s' % (string,size) 
        print "chunks: ", chunks
        saved_chunks = chunks
        
        #Cube each number of each chunk and add them together
        
        sum_of_cube_list = [] 
        for chunk in chunks:
            cube = 0 
            running_cubesum = 0
            for number in chunk:
                cube = int(number) ** 3
                running_cubesum += cube
            sum_of_cube_list.append(running_cubesum)
        print 'sum_of_cube_list: ', sum_of_cube_list
        
        
        #Reverse string if even; shift to left if not
        
        for index, integer in enumerate(sum_of_cube_list):
            if integer % 2 == 0:
                integer = str(integer)[::-1]
                saved_chunks[index] = integer
            else:
                first_number = str(integer)[0] 
                integer = str(integer)[1:] + first_number
                saved_chunks[index] = integer
                #  Remove first letter + Concatenate first letter to end 
                #  == all characters 1 shift to the left
              
        print 'Modified list:', saved_chunks     #Join modified list back together
        print "".join(str(x) for x in saved_chunks)         
    


    else: 
        return ""
```

0 is falsy though

`0 == False` is True though since bools "are" ints. 
False (a subclass of class int) is represented by 0 -> `False.real  # 0`

`False is not 0` though
`False is not 0  # True`
because `is` checks that `the_left_object is the_right_object` as in they are checked to see if they are identical; if they are the same thing.

If False is a subclass of an int, it can never be identical to an int.

```py
print(0 == False)        # True
print(0 is False)        # False
```

werkzeug is a http library, it does a lot of things. *flask is built on top of werkzeug.* basically it uses werkzeug to translate higher level statements into responses. werkzeug is also the routing engine, so it tells Flask how to make sense of `@app.route('/')`.  e.g.
```
@app.route('/')
def index():
    return "hello" 
```
what happens during production? flask creates a WSGI compliant application that will communicate via the http protocol. as i said before there are other servers for WSGI apps, e.g. uwsgi and gunicorn. you can think of those as wrapping up the flask application and then routing requests to flask and piping the response back out the client. 

>So when one is ready to deploy one would use uwsgi or gunicorn, configure them to call the flask application when they receive an HTTP request from the client.

Yup :)
@teichopsia- Ah, I'm sorry I have really confused you. :(

@wgwz You are welcome.

Ha! I've been staring at the screen for ~~over five minutes~~ trying to think how to respond. I'm officially confused :smile: 
Flask is the application logic which uses werkzeug as a development server, so the developer can observe the behavior in real time. It is there for convenience only and when you are ready to deploy and configure, it is **not used** again. But if that is true, then I don't understand how werkzeug can be used to write web applications (meaning how does flask fit into it [you did mention not as many tools as flask]) nor why is it not used as a server. 

**_________________**
So when one is  ready to deploy one would use uwsgi or gunicorn, configure them to call the flask application when they receive an HTTP request from the client.  

(I have questions regarding using setup.py but since this question in itself is quite.. hmmm, comprehensive (?) I'll leave those for later. If you don't mind, of course)

> On another point, recently I read (can't remember where) that one would use setup.py for production but wherever I read it didn't mention the why.   

Well one reason is that you can specify version information within your *setup.py*. To install it you would just do `pip install myapp` and then be ready to run it with `flask run` for further development or pass the app instance to your production server.

In production it's similar but you would use a development server, i.e. uwsgi or gunicorn. Those both know how to serve WSGI compliant python apps. You just pass the instance to those servers. The dev server flask uses is based on werkzeug. One of the install dependencies. Though werkzeug is not just a server, you can actually write web applications/APIs just with that (not as many tools as flask).

Read this article to understand in more detail why Python is SLOW: https://jakevdp.github.io/blog/2014/05/09/why-python-is-slow/

Not to mention POINTERS which, when used effectively, will make your programs gain significant elegance and power. In fact, the power and flexibility that C et al. provide in dealing with pointers serve to set them apart from many other programming languages. Long live low-level languages!!!

Secondly, Python being a high-level language, abstracts the low-level details from the user. This is bad for programmers who want 100% control over what they're doing. C, C++, and Rust allow you to manage memory manually and provide some amazing features such as threading / parallelism and low-level optimization techniques, resulting in faster and more efficient programs.
But having said all that, Python has its downsides too. First, since it's an interpreted language, in most cases it won't be as fast as compiled languages such as C, C++, Rust, and Crystal.
And Python is also heavily used in data science and machine learning because people like to make their jobs easier, they don't want to worry about low-level implementation details.

All of these reasons are why Python is so popular and is one of the most recommended languages to learn for beginners in CS and programming. MIT, University of Virginia, Rice, UMich and many other universities and colleges now use Python for their introductory first courses in computer science.
Moreover, the syntax is "clutter-free" (no braces, no semicolons, parentheses only where necessary).
Another thing is that Python's syntax is highly readable like you mentioned. If you name your functions and variables judiciously, it almost reads like English.

@ConstantFun: Yes, that's right. Python is a high-level language that provides a lot of built-in functions that make your work easier. In a language such as C with few built-in functions, you have to implement most algorithms from scratch. And you can achieve in a 3-4 lines of code in Python what would take 15-20 lines in C.

I hope my code is self-explanatory.

```
import math

class Point():
    """Represents a point in 2-D space."""

class Rectangle():
    """
    Represents a rectangle.
    Attributes: width, height, corner (a Point object that specifies the lower-left corner)
    """

class Circle():
    """
    Represents a circle in 2-D space.
    Attributes: center (a Point object), radius
    """

circle1 = Circle()
circle1.center = Point()
circle1.center.x = 150
circle1.center.y = 100
circle1.radius = 75

def distance_between_points(p1, p2):
    """Returns the distance between two points."""
    return math.sqrt((p2.x - p1.x)**2 + (p2.y - p1.y)**2)

def find_center(rect):
    """
    Returns the center of a Rectangle.

    rect: Rectangle

    returns: center of rect
    """
    p = Point()
    p.x = rect.corner.x + rect.width/2
    p.y = rect.corner.y + rect.height/2

    return p

def point_in_circle(circle, point):
    """
    Determines whether a point lies in or on the boundary of a circle.

    circle: a Circle object
    point: a Point object
    returns: True if point lies in or on the boundary of circle, else False
    """
    if distance_between_points(point, circle.center) <= circle.radius:
        return True
    return False

def rect_in_circle(circle, rect):
    """
    Determines whether a rectangle lies entirely in or on the boundary of a circle.

    circle: a Circle object
    rect: a Rectangle object
    returns: True if rect lies entirely in or on the boundary of circle, else False
    """
    # declare and initialize the four vertices of rect
    rectPoint1, rectPoint2, rectPoint3, rectPoint4 = Point(), Point(), Point(), Point()
    rectPoint1.x, rectPoint1.y = rect.corner.x, rect.corner.y
    rectPoint2.x, rectPoint2.y = rectPoint1.x + rect.width, rectPoint1.y
    rectPoint3.x, rectPoint3.y = rectPoint1.x + rect.width, rectPoint1.y + rect.height
    rectPoint4.x, rectPoint4.y = rectPoint1.x, rectPoint1.y + rect.height

    # store the four vertices in a list
    rectPoints = [rectPoint1, rectPoint2, rectPoint3, rectPoint4]

    for pt in rectPoints:
        # If any corner of the rectangle lies outside the boundary of the circle, then the rectangle cannot lie entirely in or on the boundary of the circle.
        if distance_between_points(pt, circle.center) > circle.radius:
            return False

    return True

def rect_circle_overlap(circle, rect):
    """
    Determines whether any part of the Rectangle falls inside the circle, i.e., whether the Rectangle and Circle intersect.

    circle: a Circle object
    rect: a Rectangle object
    returns: True if any part of the Rectangle falls inside the circle, else False
    """
    if rect.width < rect.height:
        if distance_between_points(find_center(rect), circle.center) < (circle.radius + rect.width/2):
            return True
    else:
        if distance_between_points(find_center(rect), circle.center) > (circle.radius + rect.height/2):
            return True

    return False

```

Here is a short script to test three string methods:
```
import unittest

class TestStringMethods(unittest.TestCase):

  def test_upper(self):
      self.assertEqual('foo'.upper(), 'FOO')

  def test_isupper(self):
      self.assertTrue('FOO'.isupper())
      self.assertFalse('Foo'.isupper())

  def test_split(self):
      s = 'hello world'
      self.assertEqual(s.split(), ['hello', 'world'])
      # check that s.split fails when the separator is not a string
      with self.assertRaises(TypeError):
          s.split(2)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    unittest.main()
```

if __name__ == '__main__':

Hello All!

@abhishekdevinfo which language to use is entirely up to you. One of the common suggestions is to use the language you are most familiar with. 
The difference (please correct me if I'm wrong with any of my points guys and gals) between Django and flask is that Django already made a lot of decisions on what to use while flask leaves those decisions up to you. 
If your goal is to learn, then perhaps you shouldn't use a framework and build everything from scratch. Do keep in mind that frameworks implement security. For example, one of the features of Flask is that it implements CSRF protection by using jinja2 templates (I think it comes from jinja2). 
However (yes, we are biased for flask), you could use flask and read the source code to see how it is implemented or simply build an application using flask and see how some of the other components fit together. Once you have that understanding then you can work backwards to see how to build your own framework (as a learning exercise or whatever)

@Chovin `pip install virtualenv`. then `virtualenv env`. (creates a dir in root dir called *env/*. ) activate with `source env/bin/activate`. e.g. `pip install flask`, then `pip freeze > requirements.txt`. so that in future environments `pip install -r requirements.txt`. when done `deactivate`.

depending on your distro, if python3 is called with python or python3 the command would be either with or without the 3
```
mkdir projectName
python3 -m venv [directoryname] [--without-pip]
```
where [directoryname] will be the directory that contains the python interpreter and all pip installed packages.
```
source [directoryname]/bin/activate  # to activate the dir.
```
if you did the above without pip and assuming you are using linux
```
wget https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py
python get-pip.py
```
I normally remove get-pip.py, but that's me.

whenever you are going to work in a virtualenv, you first activate it with the above command. Everything will be contained within it, pip installations and all. This is the workflow that works for me without having to prefix the darn thing with sudo and making the pip installations system wide.

copy paste, I can explain if you have any questions
```
# Another way of doing it. Original below.
# Up to date python development environment, withoud administrative
# privileges. Python 2.7 and 3.3
> python -m ensurepip --user
> python -m pip install --user upgrade pip
> python -m pip install --user upgrade virtualenv

> python -m virtualenv [venv_dir_name]
> . ./[venv_dir_name]/bin/activate

# create a virtual enviornment.
> python3 -m venv [directoryName] --without-pip
> source [directoryName]/bin/activate
# or
> cd [directoryName]
> source bin/activate
# or
> . venv/bin/activate

# update pip
# download 
> wget https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py
# install
> python get-pip.py
```

```
def sort(arr):
    '''Recursively sort list

    Args:
        arr: list

    Returns:
        sorted list nested
    '''
    if len(arr)==0 or len(arr)==1:
        return arr
    least = arr[0]
    for i in range(len(arr)):
        if arr[i]<least:
            least = arr[i]
    arr.remove(least)
    return [least, sort(arr)]
```

```py
# RegEx to validate that URLs are either of youtube or soundcloud
youtube = re.compile(r'(https://)?(www.)?((youtube.com\/)|(youtu.be\/))(\w)*')    
soundcloud = re.compile(r'(https://)?(www.)?(soundcloud.com\/)(\w)*')

supported_websites = {
    "youtube": youtube,
    "soundcloud": soundcloud
}
# To validate a url passed to the function, whether it belongs to any of the websites in the dict or not.
def validate(string):
    for pattern in supported_websites:
        if pattern.search(string) is not None:     # Here is where I'd like youtube variable and not the "youtube" string
            return True
    return False
```

there is a use for locals() though
but as you can see, it's just using dicts, so going with @wgwz's solution would be the safe way to go

```py
# do stuff
banana = 5
stored_varname_for_some_reason = 'banana'

# get local variable names
vars = locals()  # -> {'banana' : 5, 'stored_varname_for_some_reason' : 'banana'}

# get variable with some name
my_var = vars[stored_varname_for_some_reason]  # -> 5

# do stuff with it
print(my_var)  # -> 5
```

count = 5

The program uses a mask to perform a brute force

```
import re

def to_string(val, word, alph):
    ret = word
    size = len(alph)
    ret+=alph[(val % size)]
    return ret



digits="0123456789"
#alpha="abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"
alpha="abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"


mask = "?d?d?dl?lf?d"
length = len(mask)
tokens = {"?l":alpha, "?d":digits}
token_value = {"?l":26, "?d":10}
search_space=1
num_of_tokens=0
test = re.findall("\?l|\?d|\w+|\s", mask)
stuff=""
increment=0
user_inc = len(test)
in_lis = []
out_lis = []
print(test)

for i in range(length):
    if(i+1<=length-1 and mask[i] == "?"):
        pos_token = mask[i]+mask[i+1]
        if (pos_token in token_value):
            search_space*=token_value[pos_token]
            num_of_tokens+=1

while increment < user_inc:
    cur_token = test[increment]
    if cur_token not in tokens and increment == 0:
        stuff+=cur_token
        in_lis.append(stuff)
    elif cur_token in tokens and increment == 0:
        for j in range(token_value[cur_token]):
            in_lis.append(to_string(j, "", tokens[cur_token]))
            

    elif(cur_token not in tokens):
        for index, item in enumerate(in_lis):
            in_lis[index]+=cur_token
    else:
        for thing in in_lis:
            for j in range(token_value[cur_token]):
                word = to_string(j, thing, tokens[cur_token])
                #print(word)
                out_lis.append(word)
        in_lis = list(out_lis)
        out_lis.clear()

        
    

                

    increment+=1

#print(in_lis)
#print(len(in_lis))
#print(search_space)

  
#print(in_lis)

```

@arjunsingh81989 It's popular because (a) it's cheap (free to try out), (b) Zed gives you his personal email address in case you get stuck (I have emailed him and he really replies!), (c) the program really assumes no prior knowledge and it doesn't go from crazy easy to crazy hard all of a sudden... it really is a gradual build-up, (d) Zed teaches you not just the programming concepts but also good coding practices along the way, like principles for good troubleshooting, reading code backwards, how to do effective research online when you get stuck, etc (e) it is dead simple in that your only job is to type code in exactly as he has shown you and then run it.  He takes care to make sure that nothing can go wrong because you're copying exactly what he does first, and then only playing with it later.

So in test driven development, all the cases are handled beforehand. First you think of all the cases that your program might face and then test all the cases. And hence program is *supposed* to be fine.
This means that of you make your tests, write your code, get all the tests to pass, but you know there are still some problems with the code, that your test cases aren't good enough
In test driven development, you design your test cases first, and you design them in such a way that once they all pass, you're done coding that function/class/block of code
The idea behind test driven development is two-fold: 1) you are garuenteed to have test casesfor your code and 2) they *shoukd" be garuenteed to be good

3.8  Parameters and arguments

Some of the built-in functions we have seen require arguments. For example, when you call math.sin you pass a number as an argument. Some functions take more than one argument: math.pow takes two, the base and the exponent.

Inside the function, the arguments are assigned to variables called parameters. Here is an example of a user-defined function that takes an argument:

def print_twice(bruce):
    print bruce
    print bruce
This function assigns the argument to a parameter named bruce. When the function is called, it prints the value of the parameter (whatever it is) twice.

In python 3, this newer type of object is already the default, so there's no need to explicitly put it in as I have. Technically you only need to inherit from object in Python 2. The reason for this is that in Python 2 the default object class is now widely depreciated, so if you don't inherit from object explicitly in python2, you are missing quite a few features in your user defined class.

All together for python 3:
```
class BankAccount(object):
"""
A simple bank account class with a balance attribute 
and deposit, withdrawal methods.
"""
    def __init__(self, balance):
    """
    Initiates a balance attribute.
    Expects a non-negative decimal.
    """
        self.balance = balance

    def deposit(self, money_in):
    """
    Adds funds to the balance attribute. 
    Expects a positive decimal.
    """
        self.balance += money_in

    def withdraw(self, money_out):
    """
    Removes funds from balance attribute if remainder is positive.
    Expects positive decimal
    """
        if money_out  <= self.balance:
            self.balance -= money_out
        else:                              # This could also be handled
            return "invalid transaction"        # by an exception.

class MinimumBalanceAccount(BankAccount):
"""
A special type of BankAccount.
"""
    def __init__(self, balance):
        super().init()

```

The other way is to overload the less than operator in your class definition.  Example:
```
def __lt__(self,other)
    return self.value < other.value
```
The problem with this is that it overides every time you use the < comparison, or a function you may not have known uses this comparison uses it  ;)

There's a few ways to do it, usually you use sort or sorted... I made an example for you whilst I was cut off:
```
class Numbers(object):

    def __init__(self, name,number):
        self.name = name
        self.value = number

    def __repr__(self):
        return str(self.name)


num_dic = {
    'nine': 9,
    'eight': 8,
    'seven': 7,
    'six': 6,
    'five': 5,
    'four': 4,
    'three': 3,
    'two': 2,
    'one': 1
    }
num_lst = []

for key, value in num_dic.iteritems():
    num_lst.append(Numbers(key, value))

sort_nums = sorted(num_lst, key=lambda each: each.value) #use the key to make sorted compare by attribute

print num_lst    
print sort_nums
```

@meetmangukiya  A class variable only exists inside that class - just like a function variable only exists inside that class. So when you create an object, The myClass class code is run __in its own scope__ and the variable is created, updated, then at the end it it garbage collected. To access a variable out of scope, you'd either be looking to use a global variable, which can get a bit sketchy, or use inheritance. So MyClass could inherit from ParentClass where these things are set, or you could just pass them straight into the class at creation just like passing functions to a variable. it only becomes an attribute of the instance when you add self.*variable* = *argument passed in*

```
def class MyClass:
    """
    This is a test class.
    """

    class_var = 0    # This is a class only variable. It is not a property of the object.

    def __init__(self, a_property="round"):
        self.my_constant = "blue"    # All objects will have the property blue
        self.my_variable = a_property # All objects will have the property round unless otherwise stated

    def counter()
        class_var += 1    #Number of instances created is increased.

    counter()

 ```
    
Basically class variables go outside of your functions. It is common to put them before the init just like you declare variables at the top of a script so they are visible to all functions that come later.

@meetmangukiya  You would normally create an __init__ method for your class where you would put in variables for the object be defined when the instance is created. You can hard code these or have them be set when the instance is defined. These are variables or properties of the object. If you just want a variable to use inside the class itself - i.e. it's not a property of the object, just a variable used by some of it's methods, then you declare it as a variable outside of the __init__ method.

The audience is always our campers. We are dividing the language basics from language utilities in a way, that one can get started with the full stack projects just by doing the basics section. 

Both these sections are optional. For instance, if someone is already moderately good with Python, but has an interview in a week on Python - they can go and practice the advanced section and skip the basics section.

We are yet to decide if we are going to include a section to implement the JS basic and intermediate and advanced algos to be solved in Python (also, for interview practice).
Showing the gotchas by example could be of good help, @alayek... and I would keep it basic, IMO...

@alayek:
Checking...
Not sure about how far you want to take this "training"... Who is the audience? I am not sure about the advanced training... I wonder if we are prepared to offer a full course about things like binary trees and other data types without a good understanding of algorithms in the first place... I wonder if it is not too ambitious considering the target audience?

IMO it would be better to focus on the basics, which I think are what most of the people are looking for in FCC? (*I may be wrong...*)

There is a lot to say about that part. I would suggest to focus not on the obvious, widely available stuff but rather in focusing on the usual gotchas and best practices?
* I guess in the wiki there is something about basic data types? I don't see "sets" in your list? Possibly array should also be mentioned?
* question: "named parameter" == named tuple?
* the difference between Statement and Expression should be stressed somewhere...
* distinction in the operations between mutable and immutable data types? Very Important! Also: in place vs by copy changes (a Gotcha, specially for mutables). Here a nice explanation that could be added? http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22338671/python-functions-to-change-values-in-place. Also: many mutable methods should be used by reference. copy and deepcopy should be also stressed. I think this is one of the most important issues in python where many people have problems.
* what is "multiple returns"?

@/all we need some help with picking Python challenge topics for in-browser practice. What all would you recommend? We have room for, like, 20 challenges for now.

Before you go ahead and propose, here are some things you **cannot do** within the in-browser challenges:
- import a module that's not part of core Python 3, and  probably needs a `pip install`.
- code spread over multiple files. No module import with putting `__init__.py` in a directory.
- connect to a DB or start a server etc.

I am thinking we pick them in an order that encourages reading Python documentation and understanding what needs to be done, or which function would work better for the usecase at hand. 

Also the challenges should encourage best practices. No pokemon exception catching or `from x import *` stuff!

Whenever you call a function, your computer has to do a lot of background work. If instead of using recursive loop, you use a regular loop, it can significantly reduce the overhead to run your code. In the extreme case, if you have a very long loop, you can run out of memory (Stack overflow). In general, unless you have a good reason to use recursion, its better to use regular loops

this is just my opinion and it probably doesn't apply to everything, but i recommend separating the DB and app with an access layer, like a REST layer.  doesn't matter what it is, long as it's an API that's orthogonal to your app

my last work had one table that was about 3TB, partitioned by month.  not ginormous by today's standards, but still nontrivial
i wouldn't bother with app-level partitioning, because just plain horizontal partitioning scales like gangbusters most of the time
app-level partitioning is when the app decides which table to hit instead of the database.  frankly it's sad when you have to do it.

> :star: 299 | @ltegman | [http://www.freecodecamp.com/ltegman](http://www.freecodecamp.com/ltegman)
> alayek sends brownie points to @ltegman :sparkles: :thumbsup: :sparkles:

@ltegman thanks for sharing. Yes, we have looked at this and similar implementations of JS interpreting Python code in browser.

But this particular one has a big problem - this implements Python 2.x, and our focus is Python 3.x; which is more widespread in 2016.

Other than this, these are the main reasons we won't be doing in-browser challenges for these languages (at least not now, but this may change in future)
- They would most probably not work in all browsers, all versions. At least not the number of browsers we support at FCC. One update, and we might have an influx of issues on this.

- Our focus is on the server-side; it's better if the camper actually gets out of browser and starts using a real terminal.

- Python in-browser implementation is available; but this probably won't be the case with .NET or PHP or Ruby or Java.
